posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Flashing bootleg GBA cartridges with a GC to GBA link cable and a PC or softmodded GC or Wii can be accomplished by following the steps below.

Required materials:

- GC to GBA Link Cable
- PC with a serial port
- Softmodded GameCube or Wii
- Flash cartridge
- EZ-Flash IV Flash Kit

Step 1: Connect the GC to GBA link cable to the GBA cartridge, and the GameCube or Wii.

Step 2: Connect the other end of the GC to GBA link cable to the PC with a serial port.

Step 3: Download the EZ-Flash IV Flash Kit from the EZ-Flash website.

Step 4: Install the EZ-Flash IV Flash Kit on the PC.

Step 5: Launch the EZ-Flash IV program, and select the “Flash Cartridge” option.

Step 6: Select the “GC-GBA Link” option, and then choose the “Start” button.

Step 7: On the GC or Wii, press the “Link” button.

Step 8: On the PC, the EZ-Flash IV program will now detect the GBA cartridge, and will begin to flash the cartridge.

Step 9: When the flashing process is complete, press the “Finish” button to exit the EZ-Flash IV program.

Step 10: Disconnect the GC to GBA link cable from the PC, and the GameCube or Wii.

Once these steps have been completed, you will have successfully flashed a bootleg GBA cartridge with a GC to GBA link cable and a PC or softmodded GC or Wii.

And it's a combination of hardware + software, you need a flasher working at 5v I think (haven't messed around with any of that shit in ages, but I think it was 3.3v for GB and GBC carts and 5v for GBA ones) and a software solution to interface with the various chipsets on repro carts, there's fuckloads of these out there too. With a DS you can dump ROMs from a cart (genuine or bootleg), dump save files (genuine carts and SOME bootleg ones) and inject save files into the cart (original carts only).

>>9611264
Today I am officially starting /vr/'s first Serious Sam mapping project called "A Serious Case Of /vr/"
If you're new to mapping with SED1 then check out this quick start guide: https://rentry.org/vy4qr

A Serious Case of /vr/ Rules:
>Map must be made for Serious Sam The Second Encounter 1.07 version (this is the most up to date retail version on Steam/GOG)
>Usage of custom textures, sounds, and music is approved and encouraged
>Usage of custom entities or other mods is NOT allowed. Outside of textures, sounds, and music your map should be 100% vanilla with 1.07
>Please provide a readme listing your name (even if it's anonymous), map name, and sources for any custom content used
>Map must be beatable and have proper co-op support
>Do not make edits of existing maps
>Project host has the final say and can deny your entry if it is not up to /vr/ "standards" (please put some effort into your map)
>Rules are subject to change
>Deadline: TBD

Tips:
>Trigger a checkpoint whenever a new weapon is picked up to ensure everyone spawns with an up-to-date arsenal
>Make co-op portals for arenas that get closed off (and/or one-way doors so players don't get trapped)
>Aim to balance your map around Serious difficulty first, but don't be afraid to make support for other difficulties later
>Try to keep co-op in mind when balancing fights, drawn out reinforcement spawners are not fun to wait on
>Hot starts are not that common in Serious Sam, make a "lobby" for players to jump around in without risk of triggering anything (useful for co-op)
>A good fight is more enjoyable than a good looking room, don't stress yourself out over brushwork
>Use the official maps as references (I won't berate you for coping models, texture work, etc. from official maps) (You can have multiple maps open at the same time and switch between them on the fly in the editor)
>Don't forget to make a thumbnail for your level
>Ask questions if you need help
>Get creative with secrets!

Because the dev made basically made every wrong decision and the resulting game is simply not fun to play:
1. He spent great deal of time crunching numbers to ensure balance - but forgot to make gameplay actually fun
2. Focused on co-op multiplayer too much - even though it's not a Zandronum game
3. Giant, boring levels that you constantly have to go through
4. Couldn't keep it in his pants. Usually people are willing to overlook one weird fetish, but not two at once. If it was just bara men, or just furries, it would've been fine, but bara furries is over the line. The point of fanservice is to attract potential players, not to alienate them.

This game is extremely educational, it should be studied by any fledgling game designer, you can write long essays on what went wrong with it.

>>9612371
I decided to dig through the past few threads to get some numbers. Counting the amount of posts explicitly pertaining to SRB2K in each thread led me to these results
>25 posts of 527 last thread, about 4.7%
>20 posts of 588 before that, about 3.4%
>14 posts of 602 in the thread preceding that, about 2.3%
>Said posts are frequently about creating content (i.e. Sprites) for the game
>Said posts are also usually screenshots with little text content, doesn't take up much screen space
Going by the past three threads, SRB2K related content makes up less than 5% of posts in these threads. Said posts are so minimal that anyone not interested can easily scroll past them, even the long ones because 2000 characters is not a lot. That leaves the only argument being "it's not an FPS," but it is a mod of Doom, which is explicitly covered in the OP, reading
>Gameplay, WADs/Maps/Mods, Source Ports
(The game also has a first person view option, and you shoot people with various items, so there's that too)

In short, you're complaining about content that makes up a fraction of the threads, is easily avoidable, is infrequent to other games in comparison, harmless by 4chan standards, and is thread relevant.
Welcome to 4chan. If you don't like certain content, ignore it. If you think content is harmful, counteract it by posting content you like instead of complaining without substance.
tl;dr SRB2K is fun and on-topic, fuck off

>>9612858
>less than 5% of posts
That's equivalent to rolling a Nat 1 on a d20. I can see how some people would get butthurt about those odds, especially when it beats some unquestionably relevant series' representation, like Unreal, Heretic/Hexen, and even Serious Sam on an average day.
Of course, that can be blamed just as much on people not talking about those games as often as things like Doom, Quake, and even Blood or Duke3D (let alone SRB2K), but I still think it's valid to draw attention to SRB2K's possible overrepresentation.
Personally, I think that it being a Sonic fangame made in a retro Doom source port (assuming Doom Legacy is still the foundation of SRB2K; I wouldn't know to be honest) is reason enough to allow it. If SRB2 would be on-topic, SRB2K should be, too.

Doom wad generation is still limited as is and people thinking most custom wads are just slaughter wads will not take away the more interesting and unique wads away

Basically, "real media literacy" being knowing mroe shit and not copypasting the same conclusions that you clearly didn't copy from someone else
Even Doom is like this, whether it's Brutal Doom overshadowing most of modding or more people nowadays putting attention towards Isabelle crossovers

>>9614015
No it isn't, have you seen how much AI struggles with fundamentals? It can't even depict a hand or foot without completely fucking it up.
>"But look, AI has finally fixed hands!"
>hands are still absolutely fucked, missing joints, uneven segments, fingernails missing or melding into fingertips somehow, only difference is that it doesn't look like something else if you squint
>also the framing and composition is always the same as all the other images

AI lacks basically all the fundamentals of a brain, there's so incredibly much that goes into even a middling or poor artist to interpret and create their art, which AI has absolutely no other way of approaching but applying manually written instruction sets against high speed number crunching, the computer's primary strength. This is like cooking a steak with a blowdryer, it's so fundamentally unsuited for the task that it isn't even funny, and the increasing optimizations don't so much amount to increased heat output, rather just slightly improved airflow and power consumption.

You're pitting a century old technology which isn't even infinitely scalable like people think it is, against millions of years of evolution. The complete void of imagination, instinct, and abstract interpretation or deconstruction cripples it as an artist, it doesn't even UNDERSTAND what it looks at. Cutesexyrobutts tracing other artists results in better works than prompting an AI.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616709
>>9616714
It was fairly demanding, yeah, but you didn't have to spend $5000 on a machine to run it or anything. Mind, most people weren't even aiming to hit the peak 35fps at the time, a consistent ~20fps was considered very smooth, especially for a game like this (compare to Ultima Underworld, which ran FAR slower).
Depending on your hardware, and what you were fine with, you could knock down screen size a notch or two, or play on low detail mode, where the game still looked nuts by 1993 standards. If you were on the low end though, you could be in the situation where your computer simply didn't have the guts to run both Doom and drivers for your mouse at the same time, so it'd be keyboard only.

Hardware was also going down in price, as the market for PCs (partially driven by groundbreaking games such as Doom), developed at an insane pace in the 90s, so a pretty decent 486 computer which could get you an average 20fps with Doom 2 would be way down in price by the end of 1994, compared to how expensive it was the year before. Some older PCs could also be upgraded with new parts as well, including the processor, so you may not even need to shell out for a brand new machine to get better performance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I remember tearing apart my xbox 360 and cleaning out shitloads of cat hair and fixing the RROD. Even the radioshack employee who sold the thermal paste smugly asked me if I was doing that. It worked for a few more years until the video card melted.
Modding the original xbox is a great experience, if only for putting a huge hard drive on it and custom firmware. That thing is a monument to modern media players.
The PS2 has physical locks that you can bypass. The PSP with pandora batteries as well. The whole modchipping scene is now popular with Switch consoles. Now a freemcboot card can be bought easily and do everything you want.
I’ve heard of DJs modding game boy colors to output MIDI and using them as chiptune effects. It’s a very niche genre but I think people here can at least appreciate sounds from original hardware.
The PortableWii scene is interesting. Very interesting. There’s a whole world here to explore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've done a bunch of mods. Here's a brief list:
Famicom composite (worthless*)
Mega drive 60Hz (worthless*)
Gameboy backlight/bivert (mediocre, lots of ghosting, angles are fucky)
GBA chink AGS-101 swap (great to look at, but holding a GBA isn't comfortable as an adult)
PS1 modchip (worthless*)
Dreamcast GD-emu, fan swap (great, although the fan swap needed some extra work)
N64 RGB mod (great)
Xbox 128mb swap (worthless, I wanted to play VC3 but there's no good way to get a lightgun working on it)
Switch joycon d-pad shell (inferior shiny plastic, but having a d-pad is too important. I use them in the grip anyway, so you barely notice it)

Softmods:
PS2 freeMCboot, HDD>SD adapter (great)
Xbox softmod (great)
Wii softmod (great)

All the worthless* are for mods that were superseded by MiSTer, at the time they were okay.

Can someone recommend me a soldering kit and way to practice? I wanna start modding handhelds and replacing batteries, but I have no soldering experience beyond horribly soldering a couple of wires in a class when I was 13.
UK btw.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9615008
I'd recommend just grabbing some old electronic devices you don't care about anymore and going wild on these. Also good luck, it's really hard the first time around, gets progressively easier with time, but yeah... Don't tackle any projects until you're ready. First time I've soldered was when I was trying to install a new speaker on the GameBoy Pocket, didn't realise how fast the soldering iron heats up. Looked away for a few seconds (think the cat was doing something stupid) and I ended up burning the fuck out of the PCB. Derp.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9615008
Buy a soldering iron (ideally one with temp control), buy one of those little copper wire cleaning balls, buy some solder. You're done, now go try and solder shit to and from random old crap you have lying around until you get the idea.

Soldering is easy as shit. Soldering neatly? That's a different story, but you can get away with fairly ugly joints no problem, just give them a bit of a tug to check.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9615020
>buy one of those little copper wire cleaning balls
These are really nice to have, but you can also just buy a pack of steel scourers for like a quid and shove one of them into a mug you're not using anymore.

Oh and with this...
>Soldering neatly?
...I'd recommend either getting a desoldering pump (basically it sucks up the solder after you heat it up) or better yet, a desoldering gun - which is basically a combination of a soldering iron and a pump in one device.

>>9616652
Is there any chance that you're using a microSDHC card with an old microSD to SD adapter? I have quite a few of these around the house and some of them simply refuse to work with the faster/newer microSDHC cards. Worst case scenario, you could consider using a small form factor USB drive, like proper tiny one that won't stick out of the PS2 and booting games through OPL straght from that. Them tiny USB sticks come in really large sizes (capacity-wise I mean) nowadays, they cost next to nothing and you really don't have to worry about read and write speeds, because the PS2 won't get faster than 1mb/s, which is still faster than using discs.

Fun fact, the gameplay in Alice 1 is basically a carbon copy of Heavy Metal FAKK2, which engine it reused (McGee was friends with Ritual). All the same parkour moves and everything.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Released 30 years ago
>One of the simplest and most basic copy protections
>STILL filters just about every emulator, clone system, flashcart, and the MiSTer to this day without manual user intervention
>But it would be easy and even cheaper for a bootleg cart to have bypassed it in the day

Is this literally impossible to solve on modern hardware/emulators? The game's copy protection could not possibly be any dead simpler, it just simply writes to SRAM, and then checks if the write was successful. The game had no SRAM so it knows it's not running on an authentic cart if it passes. Ironically all a pirated cart of it would have to do is be too cheap to even include a SRAM chip and it would bypass it, even if you have no knowledge of patching/hacking ROMS, all you would have to do is inflate the ROM size to 4MB with blank filler and then it would work since the Genesis required games to use a more complicated save method if their ROMS were that large, and that's assuming you are not using an emulator that just simply has the option to disable SRAM saves. Nearly every emulator, flashcart, clone system, etc however if it sees a game attempting to save will process the save request and trip the copy protection.

Is there no way for an emulator or flashcart to know that the game is not supposed to have SRAM from headers or any other sort of information without a hard-coded list of what carts had what hardware? If this was effective how come you don't hear of just about any other Genesis game ever doing it? How come SNES emulators don't have this issue when some games on that system also tried this trick?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616723
>it improves upon the original in every meaningful way
You are now forced to obtain the sword key as Jill, reducing exploration options.
The keys are now obtained in a set order, meaning that sequence breaking and seeing unique scenes is no longer possible.
Rebecca only appears with Richard, which was a hidden event in the original game.
When fighting against Yawn, in the original 3 events could occur dependent on the choices the player made throughout the game. You either have to get the antidote yourself, play a sequence as the partner character, or are carried by the partner character. Only the first event occurs in the remake due to the complete removal of all choices.
The true opening of the game is changed and made nonsensical. In the original, the player would be left in the main hall after the first encounter with any door to choose from. In the remake, all of the paths are locked or are immediate dead ends, with the only actual path being a linear straight line to get a crossbow, filled with constant tutorializing the original never had (in addition to the remake still having Barry say he'd be searching over there, which he isn't).
All optional rooms from the original are made mandatory with the exception of the aquarium office, but that contains the crest that unlocks the magnum so it is basically not optional.
Getting the crank is turned from a couple seconds of stair pushing to a walk down a straight forest path (which makes no sense as the reason they don't leave the mansion is because of the dogs, and dogs never spawn here). You go through two "puzzles" that essentially solve themselves with how braindead they are, and it concludes with the laughable first Lisa encounter, where she knocks you out and then does... nothing before fighting you when you wake up.
The Guardhouse is turned into a straight line with zero exploration despite that area being the most open to expansions given its size in the original concepts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616723
>>9616780
The process of getting anything done in Neptune's room is extended to the point of annoyance, turning a relatively short sequence into a several minutes long one of running around in a very dull and very empty environment, complete with a return trip if you want to use the V-Jolt. You also lose the box pushing path for seemingly no reason other than to force the player to use the other door for equally little reason.
The library in the mansion is reduced from 3 rooms, one hidden and one hosting a puzzle, complete with their own files and unique environments, into a more generic library to be a boss arena for a far easier Yawn boss fight. None of the elements of the original library are replicated.
The Yawn boss room is turned into an incredibly simple pushing puzzle where going through the grave is now mandatory, instead of being optional.
The hunters are less of a threat since the game adds shortcuts that reduces their presence in route planning immeasurably.
The caves are expanded but nothing interesting is added, just another box pushing puzzle.
The "lore" surrounding Lisa is the BOW equivalent of a Mary Sue, where she's incredibly special and important to every advancement Birkin made and is also partly immortal.
The caves not leading right into the lab results in several minutes of time wasting where the player runs through pretty much entirely empty hallways in a straight line back to the main hall.
The MO Disk Hunt only starting in the lab reduces any interesting exploration for the player, effectively making them not think about the future by removing any items that will be used in the future.
The lab puzzles are pretty much the same, just with extra steps, while the lab itself has zero expansions whatsoever beyond literal walking towards the end.
The game removes all past unlockables from RE1 and replaces them, meaning no original costumes, weapons, or modes. This means no Battle Game or Advanced Mode.
It sucks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9596872
>brightness is at about 50% now
That sounds like too much. I have my Trinitron at 3 ticks out of 24 or so, while keeping contrast around the middle of the scale. There is some really slight black crushing, but I get almost true blacks this way.
Remember that "brightness" is the black level setting, and "contrast" is the actual maximum brightness. This has been mislabeled for decades, confusing people to no end. Fortunately some manufacturers have started to change this naming convention to better reflect what those settings do, like LG with their last year OLED models.
Now, to do this adjustment properly you'll need to sit in a dark room and bring out a brightness test pattern of sorts, for example the color bars in the 240p Test Suite. Then you turn down the brightness all the way and make your way up until the bar nearest to black gets barely visible (is a bit brighter than black). Similarly for the contrast, you want to avoid near-white highlights getting blown out, so you should be able to differentiate the value that's nearest to white from pure white. Realistically, you'll probably have to settle on some sort of compromise between true blacks and a bit of black crush as no display is perfect. But hey, that ghosting should be gone at least.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9604227
240p is strictly speaking an implementation of 480i, with a caveat. 480p is nice at least in principle but it's a pretty narrow subset of displays that can do it and handle 240p input timings properly through the same input (Dreamcast and PS2 are the only consoles with both 240p and 480p games, and not a hell of a lot of the former discounting backwards compatibility, and Dreamcast has issues with games and/or resolution modes outright not supporting certain connectors itself, but still) I don't know a lot about the Dreamcast, but PS2 and Gamecube tend to lower color depth for 480p so it's not an absolute upgrade and probably depends on how your display handles each and your personal preference. On an LCD with bad deinterlacing 480p is going to shit on 480i obviously.

>>9615709
should be pretty easy. If you don't find an already made cart, there's plenty of chink sellers that will just flash with whatever rom you want.
Although it'd probably be better to just get a flashcart

That said, IMO the SNES version of 240p test suite isn't ideal. There's the whole issue with SNES having an internal resolution with a 8:7 aspect ratio that gets stretched to 4:3 with nonsquare pixels. I'm not sure if 240p test suite takes this into account, meaning it's possible if you calibrate geometry using the SNES version it'll be wrong for everything else.

If you have other consoles there are easier ways to use the suite. You can run it off dreamcast since most DCs don't need to be modded to play burned CDs, or run it off a hacked Wii for instance.

Both of them have Ocarina of Time which is the exact same as the N64 1.1 version for non-speedrunning purposes. The only real, true change is that all the button icons are changed to look like the gamecube ones, so B is red and Z is shown as L.

The thing with Majora's Mask is that it's super buggy and prone to crashing all the time, don't know what it is but because of how saving works in Majora it can lead to you losing an hour or more of progress because the game decides to crap itself. The controller setup, while serviceable, is not quite as optimized for the game, especially when taking differences in stick sensitivity into account (at least for me, aiming was always harder in the GC version). These days, if you absolutely have to play on real hardware, I'd go with the N64 version, but only if you have a CRT to go with it since N64 games look like ass otherwise. Otherwise, I'd just emulate, since that's what you'd be doing with the GC version anyway.

As for MM, stay away. It has random crashes, and MM is the worst possible game to have such a problem.

>>9610640
Hi OP, I just played through both of these the past year, so I can give you a fresh and honest opinion.

First, it’s a superior way to play the NES games because you can press a button to save the game, instead of needing to commit suicide or press a button on the second controller. NES games run great, you can move with the joystick.

Ocarina of Time and Master Quest run very well, with the later adding some very challenging content. You can set the C buttons either to X, Y, and Z or use the directions on the C stick. I ended up using the C stick since it was easier to visualize. It was a little weird at first, but after a few hours I was a pro at flinging the stick to use items. Z targeting becomes L targeting which is just as effective. I really enjoyed playing these with the GC controller. As for the content, it has dome minor changes like the fire temple music, mirror shield, etc.

Unfortunately, what people are saying about Majora’s Mask emulation is true. I had a lot of problems with slowdown, it got pretty sluggish at time, and it crashed once while I was halfway through the (very, very tedious) beaver race quest. I didn’t have any audio issues, I was playing with rumble off. I still managed to beat the game without dying and still had a lot of fun with it.

;tldr, they’re great and worth getting if the price is right

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For me personally: Ape Escape, Jumping Flash 1 and 2, and Klonoa: Door to Phantomile are all extremely aesthetically pleasing and well thought out. I extend aesthetic to include the way the game presents through audio as well, all those games have such nice color choices, character design and environments alongside music that fits impeccably to the environments.
Klonoa especially has some of my favorite enemy designs ever. There's thid part in the forest world, where you have to walk a full U-Turn path that encircles a massive wooden gear - the first time you pass it, the enemies (iirc) are flying blue Moos - the second pass, once the gear is in motion, instead contains two very alien looking enemies that appear nowhere else in the game. I never knew why they did that when it seemed so arbitrary, but my instincts are they created something cool, wanted it in the game, and put them in just to do it, just for visual variety and to just kinda be noticed. I love things like that.
I guess all 3 games sort of represent that certain type of Japanese aesthetics and design where it captures all the high notes but without it being under the umbrella of anime. I like when games do that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Should also mention Astal and Lomax have beautiful pixel art that still is unparalleled imo, freakishly pretty games. Rayman as well, I feel bad for just now remembering that one.

>>9615028
NES
>Batman
>Gremlins 2 : The New Batch
>Vice : Project Doom
>Friday The 13th
>Snake, Rattle & Roll
>Ducktales
>Splatterhouse : Wanpaku Graffiti
>Shadowgate
>Lone Ranger
>S.C.A.T.
The last is a sidescrolling shooter, but it gives you the grace of having a pair of "Options" by default, which you can leave to sweep back and forth to provide an arc of covering fire, or lock in position to help with focusing certain fire.

Game Boy (Color)
>Wario Land (probably one of the best 'Mario' games)
>Wario Land 2
>Pokémon Red/Blue/Yellow
>Pokémon Gold/Silver/Crystal
>The Legend Of Zelda : Link's Awakening
>The Legend Of Zelda : Oracle Of Seasons/Ages (in case you missed these)
>Metroid II : The Return Of Samus (ditto)
>Tetris
>Kirby's Pinball Land
>Duke Nukem
Duke Nukem is a re-imagining of Duke Nukem 2, in a rather cartoony style. A lot better than you'd expect from seeing the Duke Nukem 3D artwork slapped onto a Game Boy Color cartridge.

SNES
>Super Metroid
>True Lies (was also on Genesis in virtually identical guise)
>Arkanoid II : Doh It Again
>Wild Guns
>Harvest Moon
>Clock Tower
>Actraiser
>Final Fight 3
>Kirby's Avalanche
>Earthbound
Earthbound has an overblown reputation (yet also an exaggerated hatedom), and can be slightly rough to get into, but it has a lot of charm, and is worth taking a look at if you like JRPGs. There was nothing else like it back then, and later imitators don't compare.

Genesis
>Puyo Puyo
>Splatterhouse 2 (the first one was only in arcades and on TurboGfx16 in the west)
>Splatterhouse 3 (consider the Japanese ROM for a far less sadistic time limit)
>Shining Force
>Quack Shot : Starring Donald Duck
>Ghostbusters
>Columns
>Devilish
>The Ooze
>Zero Tolerance
There's also Michael Jackson's Moonwalker, which maybe isn't all that great of a game, but it's interesting for its novelty, and for hearing some sweet tunes transcribed to YM2612.

I'd have thrown in GBA as well for a full 50, but maybe later.

Donkey Kong MiSTer core is based on an older FPGA core... from 2004. It has to be rebuilt from scratch based on more recent knowledge of the machine. Many of the core's inaccuracies were also present in MAME for years and eventually fixed.
Also, anybody who claims that FPGA is more accurate than the software emulation by default is a misinformed fool who has no idea how HDL development works.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616460
Many 70s/early 80s arcade games used discrete analog audio circuits to generate sound effects. They are pretty complex to rebuild in emulation (MAME used prerecorded .wav files with Donkey Kong for ages instead of emulating the circuits). FPGA doesn't offer any advantages with their recreation either.

the soul of an actual monkey was extracted and compressed into a chip, and that's where the sounds and some of the game logic (mainly RNG stuff) comes from - this can only be partially simulated by FPGA technology, and reproducing it using the original manufacturing technique is difficult since that species of monkey is now considered endangered

>>9590467
Tiger-Heli is probably the best beginner shmup there is as it forces you to learn all of the basics to complete it without dying, and also has very forgiving checkpoints. Ideally, you want to practice sections without dying though, as you can just brute-force through sections with dying.

It's just a very basic game that beginners would probably find too primitive/boring, and the main flaw is just that the terrain and enemies are so limited that it's hard to actually know/memorize which section you're at because it all flows together.

Any shmup can be your first it really, depend on the dedication you want to poor on it, even more true when nowdays you have training tools, adjustable auto fire,rewind and save states which make the training way more efficient and short.

Also be aware that some games can be average to hard to 1CC but very hard to insane 2ALL ( 2nd Loop), some Psikyo games are like this for example.

Now for the recommendation I try to give you some easily emulated or game available on steam or ACA :
Relatively easy.
Dariusburst AC : depend on the route but it mostly easy/mild hard at best for an 1CC)
Akai Katana got released last month it's a mild difficulty cave with a lot of thing to learn from.
Area 88 is fun arcade game you may learn movement and placement, learning curve is kind of flat but expect a small pick at level 5. give the snes/sfc version a try too.

Normal
R-type leo is kind of the same you may also learn some stuff about force and option (harder at level 4).
Fighting Hawk is close to Area 88 but as a verti. not too hard not too easy
Metal Black is between the 2 but you won't learn that much from as the game is weird AF.
some others weird shmup ; fun but wont learn much from them.
Xexex mild 1CC on the japanese version. (2all is another story)
X-Multiply is slightly harder to 1CC but at least you won't have a burnout dealing with it 2ALL even if it's hard.

Mild hard
Game Tengoku is cute nice and fun and you will learn tons of shit and tricks, but 2ALL is on another story, way too hard for it own good.
Dragon Spirit is old but it one of my favorite games ever, it come from a time where you needed a separate button to shoot sol enemies. Maybe a little bit long and learning curve can be a bitch.
Outzone depend on the version and weapon management can be a nice game to pick.

Also most Psikyo and Cave games 1CC can be put here.

There are no cheap games for the AES even cartridges sold in Japan are a minimum of $75. Also all the cartridges are the same they are not region locked. The console holds the language data for the games so if you buy a cartridge in the US and put it in your japanese AES then the game is going to be in Japanese. Realistically your best bet is either emulation or buying one of those 161 in 1 cartridges.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9615518
PAL Gamecube games run at 50hz, which means that they run 17% slower than NTSC 60hz games. A lot of PAL Gamecube games have the option to be ran at 60hz, but many don't.
I guess because the PAL games have a hz selection screen, they didn't include a 480i/480p selection screen, even though the hardware allows the games to run at 480p.
If you want to run your games at 480p, you need to make sure your Gamecube has a digital AV out port. Gamecubes made after Q2 2004 don't have this port. Your Gamecube will need to be connected to your TV by either component or an HDMI adapter, and you will need to use Swiss, which requires a boot disc (often wind waker or mario sunshine) and a memory card with Swiss and your game's exploit (ie: shinehax for mario sunshine) on it. You can make this memory card with a softmodded Wii with Gamecubee memory card slots. Alternatively, you could probably buy a premodded memory card online.
If you're playing on a CRT, you'll have to use the analogue AV out, which doesn't support 480p, in which case you can ignore basically all of that.

>>9615409
Hello OP, I have a pretty robust Gamecube collection I've been working on for years and wanted to give you a little general advice.

When it cones to starting a collection, there are a few things to consider. I think a collection is most appreciated when it represents the tastes and spirit of the collector. That being said, its possible for you or anyone else to get into Gamecube even with the recent high prices if you set your goals correct.

For instance, you may be be totally happy building a collection just consisting of Paper mario and 5 or 10 other games you really enjoy. Set a goal to get there. If you have more disposable income it makes it easier obviously but even if not you can collect it slowly over time. Start with Paper Mario, the game is up over 100 dollars now but if you keep an eye out you can probably snag it around 80 CIB and in good shape if you're willing to hunt around a few months. Also, maybe you have some other things you could sell towards that game. Games you own but don't really care for, some old guitar that's been sitting in your closet collecting dust for 10 years, whatever. Use the Marie Kondo method to find what sparks joy to get rid of and apply the same method to the games you build into your collection.

I had the fortune to collect some Gamecube games before the price jump but still finish my collecting during 2020 and 2021. Just collect slowly and thoughtfully and it will be a rewarding experience for you.

I've gotten into collecting for several consoles that people say its "too late" to collect for by this method and its been an enjoyable experience. Even after collecting those games its also been a good investment as the value has steadily risen compared to what I paid, which is cool- not that I'm planning to sell anything now. Good luck.

>>9616039
Swiss is a homebrew loader for the GameCube, that can run retail GameCube games off an SD card. You can either launch it with picoboot (raspberry pi pico soldered to GameCube), a boot disc (soldering a modchip to the GameCube drive), or with a hacked save file and a compatible game. Given you have a WiiU, I'd recommend just using (or getting) a GameCube USB adapter, and Nintendont on the virtual wii on the WiiU. It'd be the simplest thing to do.

Thematically Crash 1 is easily the best of the three, from the journey to the art direction and selection of levels. It also has the best level design overall with some devilish levels. What holds it down is its save system, its lack of analog control and the box mechanics, which are all fixed in the remake but the remake, while it does a decent job, does not hold a candle to the original in the charm department.

Crash 2 is fantastic and arguably my favorite despite not being the best in my eyes. It's great all around but does have less interesting themes. In terms of level design, the ruins, snow and dynamo levels are the closest to Crash 1 and I wish there were more of them. The sewer levels look and sound great but aren't very fun nor memorable imo.

Crash 3 is the weakest and has some truly puzzling design choices. Half of the levels are just bad/uninteresting, most notably the medieval, jet ski and underwater levels while the egyptian, future and arabian levels are excellent.

Boxes aren't saved if you die after breaking a checkpoint box, which means that you won't obtain the gem even if you break all of them if you die and respawn at a checkpoint. >>9614368
The Saturn version of DOA is superior to the PS1 version, this is not debatable.

The Dreamcast version of DOA 2 is superior to the PS2 version, but that's mainly because the publisher tricked the dev team into releasing an in-progress build before it was done. It might have looked a lot better if it had been given a little more time in the oven.

>>9616005
The PS2 only having 4MB of VRAM and no hardware AA really hurt it in the beginning. Devs were able to work around this over time and get some very impressive results from the hardware, but some of the early PS2 versions of games that also released on the Dreamcast were pretty rough in comparison.

It's funny though, because the same thing happened with the PS3, only it was due to Cell being new and the hard 256MB RAM/256MB VRAM limits that the console had, as opposed to the unified 512MB of RAM that the 360 had.

We used to see pretty big differences between different versions of a console game, there were usually pros and cons for each one. There are a lot of /vr/ multiplats where you can tell which version you're looking at just by a single screenshot. Nowadays we just get the PS/XB versions that are basically identical, and then a Switch version that looks like shit.

>The Dreamcast version of DOA 2 is superior to the PS2 version, but that's mainly because the publisher tricked the dev team into releasing an in-progress build before it was done. It might have looked a lot better if it had been given a little more time in the oven.

the arcade version of DOA2 uses the Sega NAOMI hardware, which is basically the arcade version of the Dreamcast. But NAOMI does contain more memory has faster loading. The Dreamcast port looks identical, but on closer inspection the textures are a little lower resolution on the DC, and there are a few other differences. For the time, the DC port was deemed basically arcade perfect.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9610126
It's mostly likely that a leaked clock capacitor is what caused this. It is a well known issue with the OG Xbox from hardware versions 1.0 through 1.5 - so almost all of them. Only 1.6 are exempt from this problem I believe. Since you meantioned the system clock not working it's pretty much guaranteed that it leaked and ceased to function. The end result of this failure is the acid corroding the circuits underneath or near where the cap is placed on the board, eventually killing the power button. To repair this is beyond my knowledge or capabilities. I can't even tell you whether it's a feasible option or not. This is why every single Xbox out there that's below hardware v1.6 needs to be openend and have it's clock cap removed or better yet, replaced - the system can run without it, as you have seen since yours is dead. RIP your Xbox

>>9610204
The process to fix it will be:
>remove the capacitor
>clean the board
>repair damaged power button traces

Most of the small components near the capacitor are only essential for the clock circuit, so they won't need to be replaced if they've been melted off the board.

Game Freak was a company that caught lightning in a bottle and had no idea how to handle it.
After essentially giving control to Nintendo (via the formation of The Pokemon Company) Game Freak changed from an independent gaming company to a branch of a brand management company.
A Japanese brand management company.
The Japs will almost always choose the status quo over progression, especially in larger companies.
Pokemon, as a product, is produced by THREE Jap companies (Game Freak, Nintendo, Creatures) which need the approval of a FOURTH jointly-owned (The Pokemon Co., by all three of the above) Jap company. This is before any external companies which could produce associated physical products are thrown into the mix.
Pokemon is locked into a bureaucratic quagmire (giggity). The stakeholders don't give a shit about making the games better. Their only measure of success is "not failure."
>tl;dr
Console availability and power had/has practically nothing to do with Pokemon games since the initial games' release.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9617097
Final Fantasy is not one large map, it is separate levels broken up into chunks on a linear path that you have the option of revisiting but there is little gameplay requirement to do so.
Pokémon is a single large playing field that allows you to travel anywhere at any time with road blocks. That means it IS open world, and if you don’t believe me, think about how Pokémon would work if it was 3D. I know there are full 3D Pokémon games but I have no idea how they operate, but the original red and blue done in 3D would be a large open map that you can freely roam and explore weather it’s broken up into chunks or not.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_world

The definition really is loose and subjective, but as long as the “world” is “open” it can be considered.

The kind of open world game everyone thinks about (GTA/Bethesda/Ubishit) should really be called “Dynamic Open World” but that’s too congested.

>>9612604
Powering up the fire flower is a better idea than nerfing the feather. The feather's robust mechanics are what make Mario World what it is. But the fire flower's problem is that it's scaled to the challenges of Mario 1. As the games advanced and started throwing more shit at you the strength of the fire flower diminished. There are too many things immune to it. The fortresses are filled with thwomps, buzzsaws, etc. A fire flower only serves as an extra hit in there.

They seem to notice this though. Mario 3, Mario World, and Mario Land 2 all have the fire flower for posterity but the games put a much heavier emphasis on their own respective power ups and build the levels around that.

I will say it has a lot of "pizazz". It's one of those games where shooting enemies feels very satisfying. Everything has a good crunchy impact about it. A lot of the music, and sound design is very good. The presentation is all obviously very appealing if you're a James Bond fan. I like the gimmick of higher difficulties adding more mission objectives, and I wish that became more of a thing in video games.

Depends what you're looking for in a game, really. It's probably not the most high tier competitive shooter. It doesn't have the smoothest controls. They work, but they're of their time.

Do I like it a lot? Yes. Are a new generation about to be introduced to it, only to piss and moan because it's not Overwatch? Also yes.

The N64 polls x/y axis positions of the thumbstick and button presses. Mouse aiming is just a matter of translating the position of the mouse to x/y positions the game can recognize. So yes precision is everything because those are all what the thumbstick itself can be read and interpreted as.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9605143
Guy who animated porn in Flash, mainly of various cartoons and of some anime during the 2000s and early 2010s. He was very famous on 4chan once upon a time, in part for memery he engaged in and for coming here and interacting with people, making anniversary animations for the site, etc, but in part because he was just REALLY fucking good at animating, even in the late 2000s. He was good at imitating the styles of the works he made porn of, too.

Today, in the 2020s, Flash is a fading memory, and the guy doesn't do all that much of the porn animations anymore, instead doing freelance work animating for various games and other projects (which is the smart thing to do). Zoomers had little to no idea who he was until he did an animation of some characters from Animal Crossing a year or two ago, set to an old Sandy Marton song, and it got memed to hell and back, because zoomers couldn't really handle it.

tl;dr if you're a horndog and you've been a 4chan user for well over a decade, you would probably know who the guy is.

Adding to the PMD stuff that still counts as retro

Screech is fucked up. It works outside the standard buff/debuff formula, and no amount of Defense Curling will undo a Screech debuff. Having ultra high defense stats and getting hit by merely a single one can make you go from taking 1 damage from weak enemies to over 50. At 2 Screeches, you have roughly 3% of your normal defense stat, a stronger debuff than anything else in the game.
However, if you've got a pokemon that can use it alongside a multihit attack like Fury Swipes, you can combine the two so they come out in the same turn. You can simply delete anything in your path with this combo.

Sonicboom counts as well. Normally it only hits for 20 damage all the time, but for some reason it hits for 55 damage in Rescue Team. It is also a ranged attack and never misses. Simply put, if you have it in a challenge Level 1 dungeon, 99% of the dungeon dies in only 2 uses, and you never have to get close.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
for me it's the Shock Cannon in Ratchet and Clank 3

Outside of being a space shotgun, the weapon's main gimmick is being able to charge up a shot which uses more ammo but does more damage appropriately, but also the charged shot persists as a beam for about a second, which can be swept around to deal damage in a wider area and is good for crowd control.

The "problem" with this weapon lies in the fact that the devs clearly only seriously playtested it using lock strafe controls, which has relatively slow aim and limits how fast you can sweep the Shock Cannon beam to just sweeping it in one direction before it fades. If you instead use the third person controls, which lets you fire weapons in whichever direction Ratchet is facing instead of always toward a screen reticle, and move Ratchet around real fucking fast after firing the charged Shock Cannon, you can whip the beam back and forth and hit the same target like 5-6 times with the same shot and do basically the most damage at once as possible in the game.

Probably my favourite instance of "the starting weapon is the most broken weapon in the game" because of how easily this exploit flies under the radar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616583
Peter Molyneux's last masterpiece before turning into the pathological liar we all know today. It's a weird mixture of management sim, real-time strategy and god game with light rpg elements. The idea is that in a Diablo or a Wizardry or any classic rpg dungeon crawler you play as a hero wandering into a dungeon that's populated with hundreds of different monsters. In Dungeon Keeper you're running the dungeon, building tunnels and different rooms in order to attract more and more vile monsters and then you have to keep them happy, train them up, mine for gold in order to keep them paid and so on. Then occasionally you'll end up tunneling into either another dungeon or you'll be invaded by a group of heroes at which point it becomes something closer to an rts.

Really great and unique. God-tier atmosphere. Good sequel that had a lot of UI and common sense improvements but the atmosphere just wasn't there in the same way. Still an okay follow-up though. In both games the AI's a bit shit but that's forgivable considering it was the late 90s. Only real problem is that there hasn't been a real, true follow-up since DK2. There was a mobile game that was riddled with microtransactions about a decade ago but that's it.

>Japanese/USA 1.0, 1.1, 1.2 N64 releases are alternatively known as NTSC 1.0, NTSC 1.1, and NTSC 1.2 respectively. Although they are technically different binaries, the only difference between the two is the country code byte in the ROM header, which is used to set the ROM's default language. There is no in-game language selection feature.

Wait, so the entire game is in both Japanese and English on all NTSC versions? But instead of having a language select... they hard-code which language the game will use? That, yeah, that sounds like a perfectly Nintendo thing to do. I would have assumed this was a cheap attempt at trying to region lock/discourage imports, but they already had a (pathetically easy to overcome) region lock on the N64 AND the game released with only a two-day difference between Japan and the US (Not like YouTube or Twitch was a thing back then and importing would have taken longer than two days) so there was zero point if that was the reason.

Remember Aldo's Adventure ? As I'm sure you agree, as most people do, it is one of the best games of all time. Well, I have discovered something that throws a spanner into Nintendo's infamous claim that Mario Bros. is not copied from Aldo's Adventure.

This is what I have uncovered

2. If you use Google Translate to translate the word "Yahoo" to Japanese you'll see that it is pronounced "Yafū".
3. Then if you translate "Yafu" as English to Japanese you'll see it's pronounced "Shi".

Shi..... That's right..... "Shi" is clearly Shigeru Miyamoto. Shigeru Miyamoto blatantly copied Aldo's Adventure and Yahoo games knew it so they named their company after Shigeru so that people would know that Aldo is the true Mario.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The real problem was the downfall of BASIC, which used to be a nearly universal lingua franca for every computer out there and as long as you relegated yourself to using the more or less universally implemented subset of functions you could be a full bore user developer and write software that would run on most any computer in existence, from University time-sharing systems to personal computers. Sure the OS makers and professional software writers would use a different language most of the time but countless small software businesses flourished and hobbyists themselves produced a shitload of software too.

Once BASIC went away and the industry started moving toward expensive proprietary toolkits with ever-shifting OS and dev stacks it was all over for the hobbyist industry because programming became much more complicated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9614528
It's a complicated matter, but from what I understand, the British industry had been declining since the late 60s or the early 70s. As the result of nationalist and supply and demand economic policies, there was little incentive to invest on manufacturing tools and improving labour skills. Manufacturing cost was expensive compared to their competitors, so most of the British wealthy chose to invest in the service sector. Politicians like Callaghan tried to push back against this shift and make British manufacturing competitive again by taxing the service sector, limiting pay raises and such, but it was met with heavy pushback which led to what was known as "Winter of Discontent". Thus, Thatcher was elected, and she deregulated the market while pursuing a monetarist policy that hurt British exports. Trade unions were seen to be a scary and powerful that threatened the crumbling British industry back then, but Thatcher's policy to remove their bargaining power altogether was proved even more detrimental to the industry

TL;DR manufacturing lost, finance won. They couldn't keep up with the rapid pace of the Japanese and German industry, and those who tried to save it did a few blunders that caused a pushback. Ultimately, most of the western world was flirting with neoliberal policies that reduced the power of their industrial sector as manufacturing jobs and tools were sent over to the eastern world for maximum profits, but Britain certainly doubled down on it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The answer is globalism. Most British developers were not interested in becoming part of massive mega corps and wanted to continue making the quirky and unusual games they enjoyed. However, the rise of games consoles meant you were forced to play by the rules of the likes of Nintendo, and the ability to cheaply mass produce disks was replaced with massive loyalty charges to create cartridges only allowed at high volumes.
Most of the British developers and publishers got destroyed by this, one single failure meant the death of a company, and Japanese and American megacorps eagerly scooped up all the talent and took them abroad.
This caused a massive braindrain.

There actually is still a pretty big British games industry now (they absolutely dominate in racing games post 2000), but everything produced is carefully concealed to look as American as possible to sell worldwide.

Globalism is the death of culture.

Soviet and Eastern Bloc kids were obtaining surplus computer chips, usually clones of the Z80, and making their own home computers from junk parts they scrounged up because it was the only way to get a home computer unless your parents worked for the Politburo or something like that. But all the smarter kids were channeled into computer education classes too, there. Schools frequently had computer labs starting in the 1980s, it was seen as necessary to compete with the west. It's one of the reason there's so many good Russian and Eastern European hackers and computer programmers.

Today the Russians still make Speccy clones, often massively enhanced with multiple megabytes of memory, better sound and video capabilities, hard drive support, etc.

>Can I así why do spectrum fans resent Nintendo so much?
As someone who lived right through the 80's, spectrum owners didn't and don't resent nintendo, I knew plenty of people in the UK who owned NES etc. There was no rivalry, there was more user-rivalry between sega and nintendo than there ever was with spectrum, c64, and amiga towards console etc. The console Vs home computer userbases were completely different with different needs/wants.
Home computers were a solitary affair, and no Spectrum owner etc would think twice about going round to a friends house to hang out and play on their NES or any other console for that matter.

>Maybe it's just one shitposter
Bingo, well more like shitposters, 4chan memery, and UK self-deprecating humour

>>9600617
>is that a bad boxart? cause it makes me wanna research it and see what its about

average solid platform game from the looks of it. 2d platformer in a 3d environment, like Pandemonium, or the sidescroller levels in Crash Bandicoot. The catch is that since you are a spider, you can walk up on walls and ceilings, which makes some of the paths very trippy. Also you can get weapons like bombs, boomerangs, guns, poison cannons, which turn you into a half-robotic spider with a cannon arm and such. Your default weapon is just a melee attack, so having ranged attacks will help.


Boxart is actually very accurate in that regard.

I don't know how games were sold in Europe or Japan, but in the US at least a lot of games were sold behind the checkout counters of stores or in small, 2cm by 2cm images in catalogs. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616437
>back weapons
Are you using a quad or a tank? If you're a biped they're generally a bad idea due to the kneeling mechanic, you'd be better off with some missiles.
>beam rifle
If you mean laser rifles, these are generally good generalist weapons. Keep it, get the optional parts that increase EN output and EN weapon damage/firerate/EN usage. If using it makes you run out of energy consider ditching it for something ballistic though.
>dumbfire rockets
You can try but they're generally hard to aim, you're better off with missiles at this stage.
>I haven't FELT slow.
If you can't dictate the engagement distance in AC, you're going slow. At that point you need to rely on superior defense or damage to make up for it. The back weapon is probably the reason for it, you're using a good chunk of weight that could go towards better guns or armor for something absurdly situational. Or you could ditch that dead weight to go faster.
If you want to go full unga-bunga get some arm bazookas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I like The Adventures of Batman and Robin for the Genesis for how colorful, relentless and psychotic it is, that paired with my favorite usage of the Genesis sound chip seals the deal. Seriously, look up the song Psycho Section from that game, it's unbelievable how good that shit is, the mastery of timbre and changeups and the attention to detail on the soundtrack are just unparalleled on the console. Jesper Kyd fucking rules for doing that. There was no reason that the music for a Batman game on the Genesis had to be THAT incredible, but he was given a task and he put his entire being into it and I think that mentality is beautiful.

Also the game used almost every trick the Genesis had to offer to deliver the most visually compelling presentation they could, any excuse to add 3D feeling depth and dimension to things. Entire dev team of people who refused to half ass anything, that game deserves all the love in the world.

posts.com:
The ps1 version gets shit on for missing a bunch of content. Which it is

But in some ways it’s a bit more polished and streamlined than the n64/DC version

There are less lums total, but what are there are placed a lot better imo. Less bullshit “how the fuck would I find this” and less random groups of 10 out in the open with 0 challenge or searching.

Some levels got minor or major tweaks that, *sometimes* I think are a bit better compared to their original counterparts.

The missing levels and chunks are disappointing, but the bulk of the game is there, and I find that most of what was cut was sorta just fluff usually.

It’s definitely the weakest version, but it’s still a a good game. Even if a little gimped compared to its counterparts.


If you’re a big rayman 2 fan, it’s worth trying for some variety if nothing else.

ST was generally weaker than Amiga (except for raw CPU speed which was important mostly for 3D games), so many studios were using ST as a baseline system and developing ports to more powerful system later. The same reason why people kept releasing OCS-compatible Amiga games in the 90s instead of taking advantage of AGA specs.

posts.com:
What I've always wanted for this type of game is a hack that'd comprehensively edit ALL animations, transitions, and other delay-inducing events that can occur in and around battles, removing some of them and trimming some of them and increasing the play rate of some, so as to make everything go as fast as possible while still keeping approximately all of the spirit of the original visual presentation. In cartridge-based 2D games, this should generally be possible I figure; in a CD-based 3D game I'm sure the limits of the game engine and of the hardware would get in the way much more often. But either way, there is surely much that could be done.

Of course, to do it really well you'd need to have some artistic sensibility yourself, in addition to being an excellent romhacker, and that's too much to ask of anybody who isn't being paid. So this is just a fantasy. But still, I'd like to see it.

posts.sub: How come decades later most sword games still miss basic inputs like this?
posts.com:
Spin stick and time your attack to do a spin attack, tilt stick forward and attack to stab, tilt stick right and attack to swing right, tilt stick left to attack to swing left, hold attack to charge, etc. Especially the spin always feels so good and right to do

It's the first thing I test in games with swords and more often than not you can't do anything. Examples are Prince of Persia, Fable, Genji, Crystal Chronicles or even Souls games today

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9594662
It has to do with the speed of the combat and how mobile the character is.

In something like Bayo or Ninja Gaiden you're so much more faster and agile that it wouldn't feel well. Zelda games and Maximo are much slower in combat and you move a lot less. There are sometimes inputs that use the 360 but between 2 different attack buttons, fast enough frame data to make use of pauses (eg A,A vs A,wait,A), and the many ways you can dial up an attack there is no reason to resort to these inputs which as I said are going to feel bad with how fast and agile these newer characters are.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
N64 was the "tech demo" phase for a lot of this stuff. Really showing up all of the different ways a character can control in a 3D space, and all of the different things you can do with an analogue stick in gameplay.

After that, we move into the stream-lining phase, where developers are thinking less about what the player "could" do, and thinking more about what most players are going to want, which is simplicity of controls and mechanics. That's either a good or a bad thing, depending on how you view it.

Seems like it was very common for an N64 game to have different movement speeds, climbing, swimming, crawling, ledge grappling, first person view modes, and flight all baked into the design, while a modern game like Elden Ring might not necessarily have even half of those options.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9594662
more options doesn't necessarily mean better. OoT was a very good start on 3D combat but right now I would say there are two game series that influence 3D action games the most: Devil May Cry and Dark Souls not retro though.

The prior focuses on giving the player as many combat options as possible and makes that the fun of the game. Launchers, flying attacks, guns, ways to combo enemies, parries, everything you could want to do. These games are more about being stylish than just outright winning the fight. However this limits the enemy design as these games can quickly become unfun if there's too many enemies you can't combo effectively, or if the bosses act in a way that's too limiting to your arsenal.

While the latter is the exact opposite, you have an extremely narrow set of options in combat. Block, dodge, light swing, heavy swing, shoot projectile and maybe a few more options. While this seems limiting it allows the developers to focus much more heavily on challenging enemy design based on how enemies respond and require you to use the few options in your arsenal. People generally love boss fights in these kind of games for this exact reason, every single boss is like learning a song in a rhythm game since its mostly been simplified to "when do I dodge and when do I hit?".

OoT has a lot of options that lack purpose. Yes you can angle your swipes, horizontally or vertically, but what value does that have over just hitting the B button? The answer is none because enemies don't respond to things in ways that warrant you to change that. Would crouch stabbing have any value if it wasn't just objectively the best DPS in the game? I don't think so, because no enemies have a mechanic where you need to crouch to evade their attacks. Dodge mechanics are hardly even necessary because only a tiny few enemies can threaten your shield, I can't even think of any other than Darknuts.

So I think that answers your question, quality > quantity.

Yep, when I got a Game Boy Pocket on a family trip to Tenerife, I also got a multicart for it. It claimed to be 32 games in 1, but it was more like, 12 or even 8, and the games were just listed again with different titles. Apparently some multicarts actually feature modifiers or cheats for the game when you select the alternate titles, but as far as I could tell, this wasn't the case with mine or my brother's, and it was the exact same game.

I can't seem to find any pictures online of the one I had, and I still have that thing lying around somewhere, so I guess I should dig it out and take a picture of it just for reference's sake. I don't think these things have much value, but there's some niche collectors who collect these bootleg Game Boy carts because they're fun and usually very cheap, some of the more unusual ones don't even have a menu interface, instead they have pic related, a little button on the cartridge body which you press, rebooting the Game Boy and loading the next game in line.

Pocket-protected scientists built a wall of iron and crashed a Battletoads cart into it at 400 miles per hour, and the cart was unharmed. They then built a wall out of Battletoads and crashed a car made of iron moving at 400 miles an hour into the wall, and the wall came out fine. They then crashed a diamond Battletoads made of 400 miles per hour into a wall, and there were no survivors. They crashed 400 miles per hour into a diamond traveling at Battletoads. Western New York was powerless for hours. They rammed a wall of Battletoads into a 400 mile per hour made of diamond, and the resulting explosion shifted the earth's orbit 400 million miles away from the sun, saving the earth from a meteor the size of a small Washington suburb that was hurtling towards mid-western Prussia at 400 billion miles per hour. Sorry if this gets a bit away from OP's topic, but I was sent on a nostalgia spiral on the subject of those Game Boy multicarts. Let's see, going through my memory, I think me and my brother had these games on ours, some shared, some not:
>Tetris
>Dr. Mario
>Battle City (port of Famicom-only game)
>Snake (Serpent, ergo Snake but with some added gameplay depth compared to the classic ones, has very awkward controls though)
>Flipull
>Tom & Jerry (based on that not very good movie, I liked the cartoons way more)
>Super Mario Land
>"Super Mario 4" (actually a reskinned Crayon Shin-Shan game)
>Hercules (based on the Disney movie/cartoon, was kind of awkward and difficult to play, didn't enjoy it much)
>Alleyway (a good Breakout clone)
>Othello
>Bomb Jack
>Hugo (one of those Crazy Castle games, with that European cartoon troll I never quite liked)
>Motocross Maniacs
It ranged mostly from decent to very good, so combined with the number of titles, the value was through the roof, thank God for piracy! Tetris even worked with the link cable.

>>9609792
I saw mention of an Atari 2600 multi-game cartridge which actually WAS 128 in 1, but it was one of those button cartridges, ergo if you wanted to play the 128th game on the cartridge, it means you had to press that button to reboot and cycle through each game in order to get to the end, 127 times.
I'm glad that multicarts with a menu interface are more common, I'm not sure I would have played mine as much if I had to do that manual cycling shit.

>>9613863
>>9612972
You have to put yourself in the mindset of the time.

In order to continue in arcade games you had to pay up. Then suddenly, console games are getting arcade ports at home (or games designed like other arcade games like Adventure Island) and devs wondered how you can make that fair.

For a while games tended to have hidden continue mechanics, AI isn't the only one, Rad Racer is another example from the same time period. After a while that disappeared in favour of non hidden continues, but very limited in numbers, before eventually infinite continues became a norm. These changes happened with mentalities in game design straying further away from arcade and closer to console.

Continues in AI and Rad Racer being hidden is simply because mentalities just did not think it was normal to have free infinite continues just yet, especially in regards to games that follow gameplay standards of arcade games

so yeah you can call that a cheat if you want, just don't forget the mindset of the time period when you think that. Had the same game been made a few years later, continues wouldn't be hidden, and that's exactly what happened with AI2 and 3 (the bee only helps to keep your items upon continuing)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616386
The game is on a timer, you need to pick up fruits or else you die. Fruits often appear at the last second and require such precise movement at full speed there is no way you can get them on your first playthrough (you can't backtrack).

You can get weapons to kill enemies but most of them are hidden in eggs which only show up if you jump at the right spot. You don't have time to jump at every spot. Fruits are also hidden in eggs, some levels you literally can't complete unless you find several hidden eggs. Even if you do find the eggs, you may still accidentally make it bounce down a pit.

You die, you lose your weapon, you may not find one for the entiterity of the level for all you know so you need to learn to dodge everything. Enemies and platforms are everywhere and require precise movement to avoid, alternating between a running jump at full speed and a small walk jump, etc

The game loves to troll you with enemies that appear out of nowhere or platforms that fall down under your feet unexpectedly; so even if you have godlike reflexes, the constant trolling will kill you. I even found myself in a dead man walking scenario because I was playing too slow: a jump I didn't have enough momentum to make, but I couldn't backtrack for said momentum

so the game is all about dying and dying and learning everything by heart while mastering the somewhat unique controls (this was long before controls in games were streamlined and standardized and every game plays the same), it will test your memory and your muscle memory and your patience. Oh and if you go too fast on a game over and fail to input the continue button combinatio you might as well throw the controller against a wall

Raphnet adapters are the best and most compatible but value depends on the delivery cost to wherever you live (and Saturn>USB is OOS atm).

For roms of other platforms MAME emulates you have put them into another folder in the roms folder. For Atari 2600 games for example you have to put them to
>C:\...\Mame\Roms\a2600\
Again they all have to be zipped and with the right filenames.


The base romset for the arcade games is only like 72 GB. Only download the CHDs as needed as they close to a TB and only needed for few games.

>>9610407
There are three versions of the current MAME set. Split, Merged, and Un-Merged.
Split is every unique group of roms in it's own .zip file, meaning all games using the QSound HLE will just be looking for a qsound_hle.zip in your /roms directory. You'll need the Parent ROM, and whatever Clone ROM you want for that specific region/revision of the game. Merged is the BIOS files, parent, and all clones in the same .zip file, meaning all needed files to make the Parent work are present, and with some work you can get the Clones to work as well. Which is good if you aren't picky about the region/revision. Un-Merged is the parent and clones having their own .zip files that contain ALL needed files to work. There's a great deal of duplication because of this, but every single .zip file is stand-alone and you can be certain that one .zip will have everything you need.
Split is for people who want to be efficient and have everything, Merged is for people who want to have everything but have a cleaner directory with less .zip's. Un-Merged is for people who just want to play individual games and don't wanna be bothered with hunting down all the required BIOS or device files, and don't care if they lose a GB or two to duplicate files.
Why exactly are you downloading the Split set, freaking out over nothing working right, and downloading the ENTIRE fucking set to fix it? Why not just download the Un-Merged set?

posts.com:
Get you a stable remap going!
"What's the matter, boy? MAME forgot your buttons again? That sucks!" -"Tired of having to reconfigure your inputs all the time? You're about to lose it and ready to give up? Wait! There's yet hope."

Introducing:
By default MAME instantly resets any button configuration that is being loaded or currently in use if the specified controller is not connected or drops connection while the program is still being executed. Scenarios like this include a wireless controller going into sleep mode, a weak battery giving out during gameplay or a cable pulled too early. But there's a solution: Write your own remap file using a stable controller ID and MAME's devicemap feature today - MAME won't forget your buttons ever again!

How to:
1. Connect your controller of choice.
2. Go to Control Panel > Device Manager > Human Interface Devices > HID Conform Game Controller > Your Controller > Properties > Details > pick Hardware IDs from the drop down menu and note it down.
3. Write a text document like pic related to permanently map your buttons to player 1 using your controller's hardware ID*** (see 2nd post). Save as a cfg-file and name it a single word without any spaces or special characters.
4. Put the new cfg-file into a directory called 'ctrlr' inside your MAME program directory. Create it if it doesn't exist already.
5. Open mame.ini > Under section '# CORE SEARCH PATH OPTIONS' set 'ctrlrpath' to 'ctrlr'. Under section '# CORE INPUT OPTIONS' set 'ctrlr' to the name of your remap cfg-file. Leave out the file extension.
6. Delete 'default.cfg' in the 'cfg' directory of your MAME installation. Your remap is the new default now! This step might not be 100% necessary but it autogenerates a new one anyway if needed.
7. Done
posts.filename: Games - Arcade - MAME Stable Button Remap w. Hardware ID Guide

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9612510 Continued

Result:
MAME won't ever forget your buttons again. Doesn't matter if your controller loses connection, goes into sleep mode, the battery dies or you pull the cable too early. It's Plug-and-Play now and will be recognized 100% reliably by its hardware ID.

Advice:
If you are using an 8-button arcade stick the layout illustrated below is highly recommended as it is the most suited default across all machines, offering you the NeoGeo 4-button top row and 6-button layout a la Street Fighter at the same time.

1234
4567

Note that none of this prevents you from making further adjustments to input settings on a per game basis from inside the MAME GUI if necessary. MAME creates a config file for every game you boot inside the cfg directory and those have precedence over the default which we have redefined here.

Documentation
https://docs.mamedev.org/advanced/devicemap.html

***DISCLAIMER (see 1st post)
Controller button names and enumeration as well as hardware ID will vary. Figuring them out is up to the user. It is recommended to create a game specific remap including all physical buttons first and using that as reference. It will be located in the cfg directory.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9616946
>Does anyone else find it bizarre how fucking expensive switchers are?
No, but I can understand how you would find it that way.
Like other posters said, there are some issues with quality assurance that increase the price, but that's unlikely to be the main issue.
>economy of scale
That's most likely the main issue.
It is a niche product. The are relatively few purchases of the product, which means production of the product has to remain low. Few places are producing the product and those places still have to dedicate time and resources to produce it. They have to set a price point which justifies production (and consumers' expectations).
Additional manufacturers could enter the market, but with the market being as lean as it is already every producer that engages in a short-term price war comes out a loser.
Then you have to factor in support. Support for a niche tech product.
Let's look at it from the opposite way:
>everybody poops
>lots of toilet paper needed
>lots of tp manufacturers
>fighting for shelf space/market
>cost incredibly low
>for product that's processed from sources that need years to mature
>into end result
>that billions of people deem acceptable enough to drag across their bare assholes
How much do you think it'd cost to turn trees into tactile clouds if only a few thousand people wiped their asses once every few years?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9614920
There's really no need to fix the combat.

You see; Morrowind makes you specialize. The way old table top games do like DnD.

If you didn't choose magic options in your character creation? GUESS WHAT? You're gonna dice roll on spells for a LONG time until you level it up or spend the gold for training which you CAN do. Can go total blade sword or something easily.

But if you pick agility as a main attribute and (Insert weapon skill) as one of your primaries from the get go. Then GUESS WHAT; You'll HIT WITH YOUR WEAPON A LOT MORE OFTEN! Could argue it even adds some realism to the game like imagine a kid trying to use a sword for the first time... he'd SUCK AT IT>

It's that simple. Morrowind doesn't hold your hand but there are a gazillion guides out there that can help you achieve whatever desired effect/character you want. Hell if playing on PC or xbox there are even some glitches or console commands you can use to make damn sure you never miss again. It's a little cheaty but if missing swings filters you so hard well there's always oblivion and skyrim... The watered down versions of elder scrolls that came later. Oblivion had some potential in areas but idk maybe it was rushed in development or something. The vanilla game is so fucking boring. The DLC is... not bad.

I didn't hate Skyrim; I just wasn't over satisfied with it. I play through it sometimes but if I had to choose one of them to be stuck with; it's morrowind every time.
It's got insane depth to it, a bad ass main story line. Excellent DLC. And the most memorable moments and characters/missions.
