>>9599512
After becoming an adult and getting into classical music, the series' growing pretensions from 6 onward make me think they were actually trying to create interactive operas.

Operas often only change scenes at the beginning of a new act. So to tell a complete narrative in 3-5 scenes, exposition dumps are a big part of it. It can sometimes be like an episode of Springer with a dynamic soundtrack that reacts to two characters having an argument over something that happened offscreen and the details slowly emerge as they yell stuff at each other accusingly, for example. If you imagine the flashback scenes as the group talking to one another, and Uematsu's music being written to pull you into caring about the sudden left turn of the narrative, it makes sense.

I'm not saying its brilliant or that there wouldn't be a better way to do it, but as the series got more serious, its pretty obvious that they considered opera an artistic aspiration for the series and now that I'm familiar enough with the tropes of Wagner and Italian Verismo operatic storytelling, the way 6 onwards delivers story beats feels similar to the way Puccini (Aeris' death) or Wagner (giant, world ending sword duel climax) would present them.

>>9599610
Good post. Most FF fans are completely artistically illiterate and can't see any nuance. Sephiroth is shown to be cold and ruthless even when he was a "hero." He was raised to be a killing machine, held up as a figurehead for Shinra's propaganda, showered with praise for slaughtering any perceived enemy, and we learn from Lucretia that he was never even held by his mother as a baby; he was whisked off by scientists to be a research specimen the moment he was born. You don't need to be a psychologist to see how fucked up someone would be from living a life like that. Even before the Nibelheim incident, he was, at best, a functional sociopath with a massive superiority complex, but most players completely miss all of that and take the claim that he's a hero at face value.

I'd also argue that he doesn't actually give a shit about Jenova or the Ancients. Those are just post-hoc rationalizations he uses to justify his desires. When he reads in Gast's research notes that Jenova is an Ancient, he claims that entitles him to take the planet back from the humans who betrayed the Ancients. Later, when he travels through the Lifestream and learns the truth about Jenova (that she was actually just a monster that wiped out the Ancients), he twists it around and says that he's entitled to rule the planet because Jenova was even greater than the Ancients were. In other words, all he really wants is to satisfy his own ego by elevating himself up to godhood compared to the rest of the world, and he'll use whatever excuse he can come up with to justify it.

>>9600431
Its cool being able to understand the references when you notice them. Curtains Down from Blood Money is a lot more satisfying when you understand the context of the scene the target is playing out, for instance.

The opera is called Tosca, and thats the ending scene. There's at least a dozen Kojima-tier absurd plot twists that precede it, but basically the character being executed believes that its a mock execution, because the chief of police pardoned him but had to keep up appearances because he's known for being tough on crime. Usually on stage, that character acts like a chad with no fear of death, and his girlfriend is singing these joking lyrics about what a good actor he is while the music itself is really tense and clues you in that he's actually fucked and the police chief didn't actually give the order to pardon. He gets shot and dies with a look of shock on his face, and his girlfriend jumps off a cliff to avoid arrest, then curtains the end.

So in a meta sense, the two targets are actually playing the roles of the two opera characters, and 47 is actually playing the role of the executioner. Tosca is pretty babbys first opera tier so its not hard to see why it'd be one they'd be looking for level material in, but the way they pulled it off is actually really impressive.

posts.com:
Several key parts in the MD aren't produced anymore and would have to be recreated.

>68000
Is not produced anymore, at least not in its original form (there is one weird embedded version still available but not a straight 68k)
>YM2612
Ditto
>VDP
The only bit of custom silicon. If the original schematics still exist it could be possible to reproduce the CMOS variant used in the Genesis 2 although not the NMOS VDP in the Model 1.

>>9599358
Some NOACs at least UMC ones were based on decaps of the original chips so those are highly accurate. Others may not be because they were created by just reading a spec sheet of what the chips should do and without understanding the 2A03/PPU logic at the transistor level you only get an approximation of them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9599376
also true of FPGAs. you need to actually understand a chip at the transistor level or you can't properly recreate it. there can be subtle timing or behavior you'd miss.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9599376
These are NMOS chips so decoding the logic isn't too difficult. CMOS is trickier as it's a mix of p and n-gate transistors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9599906
70s-80s chips were often NMOS logic. This is when all the transistors in the chip are n-doped. It has the disadvantage of using a lot of power and getting hot as it forces every transistor in the chip to draw current even when idling, and it also produces a lot of signal line noise and can have glitchy behavior due to how the logic works.

All modern chips (anything designed in the last 30+ years) are CMOS logic, which is a mix of p and n-doped transistors. It is much more efficient and cooler running as idling transistors do not use any power and it's free of signal line noise and glitches. However it was not widely used for years as it was more complex to manufacture and early CMOS chips were very slow (solved when they found they could just thin the metallization layer). CMOS chips are less forgiving of sloppy system design as they can be damaged by a bus conflict as that will drive the signal lines on the chip high, while NMOS signal lines would go low.

>Europe gets a lot of infiltration missions because it's a major X-COM funding area
>but alien bases are rare there because aliens prefer to put those in more sparsely populated areas
>Southeast Asia gets a lot of abduction missions due to its huge population density
and so forth

posts.com:
>>9615090
Just get the max pack from gog, its a pre-setup dosbox.
The win95 version is better, but not as stable. I don't think multiplayer is very important for you, so that shouldn't matter.

Carma 2 has some music issues, a basic fix is just renaming carma2_hw.exe to anything else and it should work, but it will crash everytime you quit.
The better solution is downloading _inmm.dll (a program used to get certain older implementations of audio to work), specifically https://community.pcgamingwiki.com/files/file/107-patched-_inmmdll. It contains some extra for variables carma2 (and many other games), install it.
You patch Carma2_hw.exe by just dragging it onto inmmcnf.exe (or its shortcut name _inmm.dll setup).
You then open inmmcnf.exe normally and add *.ogg (that's what the files should be) to the filetypes and set player to DirectShow (same for the default just in case).
You then go to the _inmm.ini tab and add the songs either via the button or dragging them on the list and then saving. You put the .ini it wants to save in the folder with the executable. Don't move the music folder as it points to that.

its always a larger hassle to write out _inmm instructions than actually doing it as its quite simple.

>>9583547
NTA, but.
Point-and-click game with copious CGI, impressive production values, batshit insane plot, full voice acting, and it impressed Nintendo so much they hired a lot of the staff for their EAD team. It's Japan-only, for the moment being. Only times it got talked about before was when collector hoarders accidentally leaked a private mega folder with tons of games including this previously lost game.
Company did 3 games like these and folded shortly after. Supposedly uses a Macromedia type thing.

Some copyright troll trademarked a bunch of stuff including the logo for the game and took down most of the media about it online, and it looks more like erasing the game from existence than a prospective new release. Nearly nothing is left online.

The game is about a 5 year old American girl identifying as a bear (and portrayed as such) going to dangerous locations after hearing voices in her head. The game opens with her being refused a bus ride, that bus is bombed by terrorists and everyone is dead, the terrorists are gunned by an airplane and everyone is dead, and the girl inspects the bus and goes "It can't be helped". Then she has to avoid dying by starvation, getting hugged to death by a pedophile cop, getting killed in the crossfire of other terrorists in a public park where a schizophrenic woman thinks the heroine is daughter, and then an alien locale that defies description. I'm saddened the walkthrough was taken offline. I really want to see how this goes now that I learned more Japanese. The backstory intro roll itself (which is in English) alone is a riot.

>>9596951
>>9596953
Anon who posted that. It's still the original files, but they are preinstalled on an emulated Windows 98 Machine so the game is easy to play

The ISO file is in a folder titled 'Files' along with the Windows 98 drive, and is mounted to the machine so the game can run, but is also there to make it easier to use and explore compared to the format of the original files

To run the machine, run "Launch.bat" in the folder

>qemu-system-i386 -nodefaults -rtc base=localtime -display sdl -L pc-bios -m 256 -machine pc,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off -device VGA -device lsi -device sb16 -drive file=Files/w98.qcw -cdrom Files/CB1_DISC.iso -boot c

Its just a one line command that launches the machine with the correct settings, but I obviously get not wanting to run some random batch script and exe, so you can also move the files to your own qemu install and it'll work fine

>>9600572
Not much, but there are two things you can try that may help.

First is to change '256' to '512' to increase the amount of memory the machine has, though I don't know if this will really help.

The other, if you are on Windows and have the Windows Hypervisor Platform enabled, is to change this
>-machine pc,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off
to this
>-machine pc,accel=whpx,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off
which will improve the general performance through virtualization

This can cause some issues related to shutting down the emulated machine though, but its nothing major

I'd like to report that it runs on Wine 7.0.1 pretty much out of the box.
32-bit Wine prefix, set Windows version to Windows 2000, and just prefix your Wine command with LC_ALL=ja_JP.UTF-8 so the Japanese characters will render correctly.
Pretty much everything works (movies, mouse input, saving and loading). This might be a more performant solution than running that Windows 98 QEMU virtual machine, plus it should work on all modern OSes (Linux, macOS, Windows).

PCem/86Box are going to be even slower than QEMU. They're full-on low-level emulators that focus on hardware accuracy. If you think QEMU was slow then those are going to be even worse.
>>9601682
>>9601691
>>9601707
You actually can run Wine on Windows by using WSL2. That way you're still using a VM, but it'll be a sensibly fast one (modern Windows hosting a modern Linux guest) rather than a bug-ridden one (modern Windows trying to run a Win 98 guest).
Just download the "Ubuntu" app from your Windows Store and then `sudo apt install wine` and hey presto you've got Wine.

For anons who are suffering from bad sound running the Windows 98 QEMU VM, it's probably due to QEMU's poorly emulated SoundBlaster sound card.
In comparison the AC97 codec is much more open and accurately emulated.
To try that, change "-device sb16" to "-device ac97".
Then you'll need to install the driver. One possibility to to search for the "SigmaTel C-Major Audio AC97 WDM driver".

>>9604896
Good or not depends on if you like point-and-clicks. As for interesting, yes. It's a pretty high level of Japanese weirdness with pretty good (for 1999 PC games) production values.

It's about a 5 year old girl from New Jersey named Cookie Blair who sees herself as a teddy bear, the intro gives the backstory that a century ago aliens arrived on an island in the South Pacific and made an agreement with the island's president where they could own a part of the land if they shared their technology with him. They eventually started an annual Olympics-like sports contest, which Cookie wants to enter.

The very first thing that happens in the game is Cookie loses her bus pass, the bus driver kicks her off the bus, and then as the bus drives away some people drive up in a jeep with a rocket launcher and blow up said bus... which causes a helicopter to arrive and blast away said people and then fly away. There is apparently an alternate version of that scene where the rocket people and helicopter blow each other up.

It's also possible to die in the crossfire of two gangs in the middle of the park, pick up a spirit radio that lets you hear (ghost?) sex, die from smoking, find Laura Croft's corpse in a tomb, win a dance-off, and break out of jail. I am sure there are dozens of other weird scenarios I haven't encountered.

It's pretty wacky.

Of course I mean inside qemu (more accurately inside Windows 98). WDM is the Windows 9x driver type, not NT (i.e. Win 10).
Once you've downloaded the AC97 driver you'll want to pass the files into the Win98 VM. To do so put the files inside an ISO file and then when launching QEMU, add a "-cdrom /path/to/file.iso" to the command.

From what I can gather, the 2000 release added Windows 98 compatibility and the 2001 release added ME compatibility. Possibly also different title screens compared to the original release. These all have different IDs assigned to them too, like how HCMW-4001 is for the 2000 Revival! Eggerland and finding out that HCMW-4002 is for 2001 release while HEG-01 is for the original 1996 release. At least going from what I could find online where I couldn't verify with photos of the games, but can be helpful when trying to find the right copy.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9606821
If you mean the audio cutting during cutscenes, I don't how to resolve that.

But if you mean the audio being distorted and stuttery, that can be fixed by disabling hardware acceleration on the sound output inside of Windows 98.

You can do this by going to the Control Panel, then 'Multimedia', and then selecting 'Advanced Properties' on the playback device. Then select 'Performance' at the top and use the slider to disable hardware acceleration.

This is caused using the ac97 instead of the sb16

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Repost from >>>/v/625694309

How you can help with a translation

Yes, we need someone fluent in Japanese, with the same skillset needed for translating audio dramas or anime (less than 40 minutes of audio).
The audio is extracted as individual files with filenames out of their context.
That translator would need to transcribe all of them to Japanese (to make later revisions easier) first.
Then give his/her own interpretation of the text in English second.

Audio files are already extracted, but not organized in a very friendly way.

>https://mega.nz/folder/IGcQ3CJa#P6VUlCjXAJxdoiZHgqBLMQ
Get this file
>Asset rips/Audio Dump WAV.zip
It has all ingame sfx, bgm and voice acting, except for the movies.
They're all short wav files named like this
>dirOpened output of nms-1683.wav

From what I noticed, they seem to be following this trend:
>nms
general voice acting (1683 files)
>sky, swm
minigame voice acting / sfx (43 files)
>cly, ffh, hdl
more minigame voice acting / sfx (74 files)
>acs
mostly sound effects and grunts and background music, but some are voice acting like acs-196 to acs-206 which cover saving/loading the game. better saved for last (216 files)

Same mega.nz folder has another file for the movies.
>Asset rips/Movies.zip
Only a handful have voice acting.
They can be hard subbed probably, but a transcription would be better even for stuff that's in voiced/written in Engrish because the audio quality is generally poor.

For the transcript to be useful it could be formatted this way:

>acs-200
>オープニングムービーを見る?
>Watch the opening movie?

as a text file, covering all of the game files.
If you don't want to type acs/nms every time you can just type the number and just clarify which section it is in the beginning of the file.

>acs-196 to acs-206
Those audio strings already have matching visual text in English even in the Japanese version.
So the acs files are low priority, but should be checked just in case.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9609140
>Dumping (and maybe recompiling) the game's scripting seems possible, but I'm not even sure if Director supports any kind of subtitles. Have to go dig through the old documentation.

>What we have now
All of the audio extracted from the cxt/cst files: Can be transcribed and given a text translation
All of the movies are in an easily editable format that can be hard subbed
All visual elements are already in English: Don't need a translation
Sprites and all of their individual animation frames are easily extracted in Macromedia editor from cxt/cst files

>How the project can move forward

>Dub route - easiest, but worst
The extracted audio can be replaced with English equivalents. Not that many voice actors. However, it would lose SOUL.
The videos can be redubbed or subtitled fairly easily like old documentary shows

>In-Engine Sub route - keeps compatibility with W95, but might be glitchy/not possible
New images are added through Macromedia editor for all possible voiced lines. English text on a transparent background.
The game logic in Macromedia Director needs to be deobfuscated (still not done yet), every single audio call will be changed to call those new textures, they'd appear for a fixed duration of time (length of the voiced line) and then disappear
Might be done via cxt/cst modding but unsure.

>Modern Enhancement Sub route - ideal, but hardest
The executable, a glorified Macromedia Director projector, is modded in IDA Pro to intercept any calls for audio playback and displays proper soft subtitles overlaid on top of the screen from an external srt file with proper timing data (might help with multi-line subtitles, and more importantly the subs are no longer held back by the engine limitations + multi language translations are possible) - of course an external text renderer might need to be coded but that's really easy
While you're at it, it could intercept mov playback and override them with AI upscaled versions of the movies

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9615226
>Virtua Fighter 2 was one of the few 3D fighting games you could play on PC actually anon.

Back in the mid 90's Sega worked with a PC publisher called Expert software, and ported many of their Sega Saturn games to Windows 95. There is Virtua Fighter PC, which was a port of the Sega Saturn Virtua Fighter Remix. There is a port of Virtua Fighter 2, which was a direct port of the Saturn game, with some enhancements. There's also a port of Last Bronx for Win95 too, and that was also a port of the Saturn game. The PC ports do contain some extras like hardware acceleration via D3D, and some games contain the arcade meshes and such. Virtua Fighter 2 was ported to the PS2 in Japan, and has a 360 and PSN port. Virtua Fighter 3 is a much more obscure game, because it was only ported to the Dreamcast.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9617085
Its fine in the context of its release date but Mario 64 is older and way better. Its a game that needs to be looked at from a 1997 point of view. It still has a lot of 2d platformer elements to it like linearity although you can move freely. Take Mario 64 out of the equation and it looks good with big open levels. Crash was out in 97, but Croc is more open and exploration based. Croc is different enough from Crash and good enough in its own way to be unique and fun in comparison. This isn’t the case when compared with Mario 64. They have a lot in common and Mario beats Crocs ass.

What else was out in 97? Jumping Flash is a somewhat similar game but in first person. Ninpen Manmaru on Saturn is similar in quality. A little less collection and a little more obstacle course. Chameleon Twist on N64 was similar in quality, it had some better bosses but more linear levels. I’d say all four are about even.

Tomb Raider was better but of course its very different. It still blew Croc and most of these others out of the water as a 3d platformer, but its a bit of an apples to oranges comparison. Same applies to Goemon on N64.

I’ve never played Floating Runner, Soultrap or the first N64 Doraemon but they probably suck. Jersey Devil is on my to do list and might be good, idk. Croc shits all over Bubsy. That leaves the Sonic World part of Sonic Jam, which controls better with an analog stick but isnt really much of a game. Let’s say croc is better than all of thesewith JD as a question mark.

That leaves Croc as a middle tier 3d platformer at the time it was released. But this was so early and 3d platformers were so primitive that they hadn’t really all gotten refined gameplay, camera and control wise. Within a few years in the late 90s many 3d platformers that I’d consider better were released on the N64, PS1 and Dreamcast. Croc is one of the best games of its type on the Saturn for what its worth, but thats a system known for having no 3d platformers.

Anyone have any experience with this thing? I like that it's 2.4Ghz, has enough buttons and the sticks, and uses AA batteries, and I can get it for very cheap. It's not listed with any actual product name or branding at the store I'm looking at, but I managed to figure out that the model name is TGZ-850M. It's made in China, obviously, and it seems that the manual is translated in that rough kind of style, if you know some types of manuals of Chinese goods.

However, it's difficult to find reviews for it, I could basically only ever find video and written material about it in South American and East Asian languages, either without translations or without much to actually say about its qualities. In fact, most you can find with Googling is guides to making it connect, suggesting either dummies don't understand how to do this, or worse, that the product has problems.

It's obviously not gonna be deluxe, but the current gamepad I have now is a wired Dual Shock-ish budget pad I bought like over a decade ago (and for even less than this). It's not great, but it's workable and has turbo, however I prefer wireless when possible, so if this thing is at all passable, I can settle for mediocre or cheap build quality. Also my current pad actually emulates the original Dual Shock behavior where the sticks have to be toggled as a mode and can't be used together with the D-Pad.

My primary concerns is the D-Pad, if it's the shitty and indefinite kind where it's really fucking easy for say, down input to register as diagonal left/right down, or worse, left or right, that's a no-sell for me, but as long as it doesn't do that, and as long as it's not complete mush, I can settle for it. I'm not that into fighting games or shmups, and I don't chase scores or aim for 1CCs with the latter.
As long as it doesn't cripple me for Super Mario Bros., Splatterhouse, Castlevanias, Zeldas, Pokémon, True Lies, etc, etc, I'm good.

Whatever you decide to get, do NOT get any of the Retro Fighters N64 controllers. Their customer service is great, but the product is fucking shit. I used the opaque grey one and the analog stick didn't have full range of motion when L was held down. They sent me one of the see through colored ones, and the analog stick again had problems, it wouldn't recognize fully forward or fully backwards. It's a bit hard to explain, but imagine you're playing Super Mario 64, it was impossible to run forwards or backwards with that controller. This could be fixed with emulators because you can adjust the detection range, but not on an actual N64. Sent that one back and they sent me another see through colored one, and this time the A and B buttons would periodically get stuck and wouldn't come back up after you press them down. I gave up asking for replacements and they sent me my money back, thankfully.

>>9613757
>Always thought it was weird how many of the coolest N64 games are Japan-exclusive, even some that could have become worldwide hits or big franchises
Although not as severely as Sega, the North American branch of Nintendo was doing a lot of fuckery. At one point there were THREE different competing pitches for a Mario Paint 64, some ignored by Nintendo of America because they didn't want to release the other one (like what happened with Disaster Day of Crisis Wii around the same time as Project Hammer... at that time Nintendo of America was openly mocking some games in official PR as the excuse why Europe had them but not America. That kind of mentality.) In the end none of those attempts released in North America, and one was cancelled and partially repurposed for the Mario Artist lineup. Mario no Photopi was on a regular N64 cart and still was snubbed by NoA (who had a knack for rejecting the N64DD or announcing on their own that N64DD software will be cartridge only in the West, which couldn't have helped the device's fortunes as it was repeatedly delayed in Japan past commercial viability despite being ready around 1998 or so (even a NA prototype exists, and the N64DD has extensive font support for English and European languages that goes unused).

Sin and Punishment was always intended to be released outside of Japan, there's some NoA credits for the translated voice acting too, but they decided to cut short everything related to it around late 1999... then somehow Conker, Dr Mario and Paper Mario were alright as late as 2001. That's one and a half years of software drought before the GC with no real reason.

No wonder NoA got a big house cleaning from the Japanese HQ shortly after to massively reduce their independence, and then some more after Project Hammer (which siphoned AAA budgets on lavish CG cutscenes for no real reason while first party games were passed over over "budget" penny pinching) and then after they killed the Wii momentum in 2009.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9613186
Do not download full romsets.
Do not bother with fancy front-ends like Hyperspin.
RetroArch is probably going to be your best choice for 5th gen and earlier.
Pick out a game by browsing the internet, reading old magazines, or talking to people irl.
When you pick out a game download the instruction booklet for it and read it completely before ever starting up the game.
Print the booklet out if you wish and keep it as a memento.
Look up some ads, flyers, and commercials to get a sense of the game's marketing campaign.
Read retro reviews and previews of the game to get a feel for the atmosphere surrounding the game's release.
Use a good, comfortable controller and chair.
If possible play on a different set-up than your desktop PC.
Consider purchasing a new controller to coincide with a playthrough of a much-anticipated game to make it feel more special to you.
I don't recommend playing console games on a handheld but to each their own. If that is what is most comfortable for you then go for it.
Do the research to get your software configuration set-up for the game and go through the process of emu config methodically. Expect it to take an evening if you are going in blind. Read the emu documentation.
Set aside time mentally for gaming. Tell yourself this is not a "waste of time". Life isn't about trying to be productive every waking moment.
Eat some decent food before gaming, junk food makes you lethargic and perform worse in action games.
When you beat a game purchase a small keepsake related to the game to put on your shelf.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: this is the ultimate Japanese working man's game. come home to a cold beer and relaxing volleyball with hot chicks in it. It's sad how much they ruined the series after 2. They lost the plot and gave in 100% to the cumstained basement dweller. No more licensed music for an enjoyable soundtrack of stupid but fitting pop music, hiding the volleyball and friendship development behind forced horny segments, it's just not the same. I think once Itagaki was gone they just gave in, he was probably the only person stubborn enough to insist on making a gravure that you could play or watch; The games after him are overwhelmingly focused on sex at the cost of the rest. Yes, the whole series is sold on sex, but the first two games have a much more quality execution and are focused on the game. After him, the games are just cheap ogling without the backbone that held it up. I think the most telling proof is in how many women are fans of the first Xbox game. They didn't come for the tits (necessarily...) but for the volleyball and friend making. That was a game that knew how to cater to more than just desperate men. I think its decline is generally ignored (vs something like ninja garden 3) because people just assume that babes in bikinis=trash game. Itagaki may be a crazy bastard, but he didn't fuck around when it came to taking a concept and delivering a knockout, at least in his tecmo days anyway.

Are you telling me that Snakes Revenge is not a sequel to Metal Gear on the NES? Yeah, I get it. Snake didn't exactly destroy Metal Gear in the NES game. But did the developers remember? The original Metal Gear was never released on any platform in English, and the only western port was the NES game. Which is the Metal Gear game that most get nostalgic for. The NES game sold like as million units, and Snakes Revenge was a NES exclusive sequel made by one of the Konami console teams. So, when Metal Gear Solid was announced, a lot of the western hype came from people familiar with the NES Metal Gear games. Metal Gear Solid does have a recap for the first and second MSX games, and most people probably thought Metal Gear 2 was referring to the NES game; Snakes Revenge. You can buy the MSX games now on GOG and steam and other digital services. But back in the day, they were obscure outside of Japan. But the NES games were not.

>>9616972
Game tends to crash with an Expansion Pak installed

Apparently for some reason it tries to access memory outside of the 4 Megs the N64 has, it of course can't since the N64 does not have enough memory to access an address that high but somehow the game runs perfectly fine with this failing. The Expansion Pak however increases the memory enough so it's now accessing a valid location in memory and this can lead to random crashes for some reason.

I think it was fixed in the PAL version but was present in the NTSC versions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9617017
I don't think that's the reason. Usually those try to write to something that should not exist on the game/console, generally to a location in the save data that should not exist due to the game either not having a save function or having a smaller save chip and trying to write to a larger location. There would be little reason to expect any type of copying device to let the system have access to more RAM. Even if the device did have additional RAM, it would be reserved for itself, not mapped to the console that would have no way of using it officially as it was not designed for it.

Also the N64 had the slot for a RAM expansion since launch, every dev should have known it was a possibility the system could get a memory expansion. Furthermore the game came out on October of 1998 and the Expansion Pak on November of 1998. They definitely would have gotten news far ahead of time if not given a warning to code their games with expectation of increased RAM since the launch of the N64.

Also it's just random crashes, you can plow through the game enough if you are willing to put up with it. It's not like Earthbound that keeps making it worse and worse on you before crashing at the final boss and erasing your save. It doesn't really stop you from beating the game eventually.

They basically fucked up by not testing the game on a system with the Expansion Pak installed, or not testing it thoroughly enough.

>>9616153
Watch a guide to open it up to board level. Then cut small strips of tape to cover the inside edges of the conductive metal pads. This guide is for the switch pro controller, but if you scroll to the end it's the same idea: https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+to+Fix+D-Pad+Sensitivity+on+Switch+Pro+Controller/124493

The only thing is, the amount you cover the pads will affect diagonals sensitivity. So you may need to redo the taping if you do too much or too little.

If you are too good at taking and defending your turf, the game punishes you by taking away any challengers. You have to leave at least one territory for each opposing gang if you want to be able to defend or invade turf again later. Can be somewhat fixed by glitching the game to create turf all over the map, but it's a half-assed solution.
Also, despite taking over the entire city, you really don't gain any benefit for doing it besides knowing there won't be other gangs waiting there to shoot at you. Pretty much everything else in the game will reward you for being good at it, even dancing can come in useful for the dates. Your reward for getting all the turf is no more gang wars to enjoy.

- Las Venturas felt pretty empty besides the casinos

>>9608448
Okay, let's start at the end(?), GTA III is the only game that "really" happened 1:1, in real-time.
Vice City Stories is Lance's recollection of his brother and his adventures when the two first arrived in Vice City, maybe it's survivor's guilt, but Lance puts Vic on a pedestal, hence why Vic practically babysits Lance the whole game.
Vice City is a movie by Tommy Vercetti showing his rise to power, more or less, decide for yourself what mission threads are in the movie and what had to be taken out for time.
San Andreas, okay you're gonna have to just keep up with me on this because this is REALLY autistic, Carl is a small-time criminal from LS, goes to LC, and comes back to LS, everything up until the Desert actually happens, Carl DID buy the air field, but the only mission that really happens is N.O.E where you have to drop supplies off on the other side of the map, everything else is a dehydration hallucination because Carl's too stupid to hydrate while watching flight videos and spy movies, The Truth missions are Carl and the Truth tripping out on Peyote in the desert, talking while Truth tells Carl about all the stuff he knows, the game picks back up with reality when Woozie calls Carl and tells him about Las Venturas, the two become partners Carl saves Madd Dogg and that's how CJ became a success, Toreno was grateful for CJ not only taking down the Loco Syndicate and delivering those supplies, and Sweet is miraculously let go.
LCS is another game that happened in real-time but it's not 1:1, some parts are more embellished, and could be chalked up to dreams and Tony leaving the TV on after a hard day.
Manhunt is a MSNBC documentary/news story, spliced in with snuff films because some high schooler wanted to be edgy, taped over, as we all know a Children's Show about a robochef.
Bully is Jimmy's story about Bullworth, some things like busting people out of asylums never happened, but to spark interest to the audience is sprinkled throughout the story.

I think what brings me to older games is that I have a sorta fascination with the material of games, and that is more visible in older games (sorta like the difference between novels and poetry). What I find beautiful isnt the beating of the game, what I find beautiful is the discovery of the seams. Figuring out how exactly they got NPCs to move a certain way, or seeing what decisions were made to make the world feel more alive. I dont think that the idea of being "lost in the magic" and seeing the scenes are mutually exclusive. Sorta like how going on the Universal Studios backlot tour makes you appreciate movie trickery more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9600430
1 is a straight up isometric metal gear
your offensive choices only stun enemies, core gameplay is about stealthing around enemies over several dungeons, its old school linear (stage 1, stage 2, and so on) no rpg mechanics

Boktai 2 introduces stats(STR,ENG,AGI), level ups, a variety of offensive options, you can now defeat enemies or still stealth(backstabbing triples damage) and a decent sized connected world map with a hub in the middle, progression is linear like modern zelda games (must beat dungeon A before you can visit dungeon B) but you have a certain degree of freedom to roam, grind and craft itens

Boktai 3 ditches the connected world map
and goes back to stage selecting, bigger dungeons but outside dungeons you only interact with npcs through menus

>Also can I enjoy 2 without having played 1?
Yes, you get a recap at the start of the game

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9613292
As I said, no. The special chip lies inside the Paprium cartridge and does its own computations, in addition to the Mega Drive's. When you dump the game, you're dumping its data, not its components. Let's use a crude example, think about a book. The game would be the pages full of letters, while the chip would be the typewriter (ancient, I know). You don't transcribe a typewriter, but create a simulacrum which does the same job. There's no special chip (Datameister is the one Paprium uses) inside any Mega Drive, Everdrive or emulator, because it wasn't replicated yet. When (and if) it does, an updated version of the emulator or flashcart will be needed, bringing along the changes pertinent to the replication.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Has anyone else played Dog's Life on ps2? It's an odd game that fits my niche of games set in rural locations and games about animals.

I'm not a big fan of fart humor, but dogs and poop go hand in hand so I guess it works in this case. I took a shit on a hotel bed.
The game's visuals are all over the place. I thought the environments looked pretty nice, most of the animal models looked okay, but the human characters are painful to look at.
The ending takes a hard turn that gave an otherwise child-friendly game a T rating. Scenes like that would get cut before release, but that didn't happen and that's pretty great.

I didn't like how the game forces you to be in 1st person mode for most of the game to collect scents. It's like the opposite of Spyro: in that game the gems shine no matter how far away you are, but in Dog's Life the scents are only visible when you're nearby so it's really hard to find the one you're missing. I'd recommend just skipping the 50 scents in each area. There's no reward for 100% anyway.

>>9607112
I just got finished playing AoD. I think this game was excellent when it came to the music (that main menu theme!) and the overall plot and presentation was great. Lara never looked better imo. The gameplay is what kills it. The last levels from Strahov onward are simply unfinished and cut extremely short. I would have loved to see more of that world and the stuff they would have us raid from tombs. Each classic tomb raider game really did something completely different from the last one. Collecting an Atlantean artifact from lost civilisations that developed from a cataclysm, destroying an Italian cult focussed around a Chinese dagger that turns you into a dragon hunting through sunken ships (interesting choice of tomb), Collecting meteorite splinters from all over the world for a weird social darwinist gone power-mad only to then kill him, and then a game focussed around the apocalypse being started by a haughty Lara picking up the amulet of Seth (1999 had many apocalypse plots, even V:tM Redemption), Chronicles was all over the place, and finally this weird cinematic plot of a serial killer and Icons that you need to collect and periapt shards you need to defeat the weird half-angel Nephilim race.

Tomb Raider was a wild ride. It really pisses me off that the gameplay for the final game was so piss-poor. There is lots of potential in that game and afaik they wanted to do so much more. TR Legend is just a big dumb action game with quicktime events that is over before you know it and doesn't really do anything with the king Arthur plot, not for all the dumb talking they do over it.
